items.author: James Berardinelli
items.content: Not only is it a thrill-a-minute ride, but it has one of the best film villains in recent memory, a hero everyone can relate to, dialogue that crackles with wit, and a lot of very impressive pyrotechnics.

items.author: Mike Clark
items.content: The result is a foot-stomping rouser. Where else can you get a cop in his underwear boogalooing with skyscraper terrorists? [15 July 1988, Life, p.4D]

items.author: Desson Thomson
items.content: A firepowered, blood-drenched action picture that doesn't let up.

items.author: Peter Stack
items.content: Slick, glossy, overblown, implausible. [15 July 1988, Daily Notebook, p.E1]

items.author: Dave Kehr
items.content: Has everything but a personality. [15 July 1988, Friday, p.A]
Has to be the most excessive film around. It piles every known element of the action genre onto the flimsy story. [15 July 1988]
A triumph of slick direction and lowbrow thrills, marred but not spoiled by a sour aftertaste.

items.author: Kevin Thomas
items.content: As a grand flourish of cinematic technique, it is awesome; as a human drama, it is disgusting and silly, a mindless depiction of carnage on an epic scale. [15 July 1988, Calendar, p.6-1]

items.author: Richard Schickel
items.content: What Willis proves in Die Hard is that it is not one you can ease through, especially if your preparation runs more to body building than to character building. [July 25, 1988]

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: On a technical level, there's a lot to be said for Die Hard. It's when we get to some of the unnecessary adornments of the script that the movie shoots itself in the foot.
